member.name: F:Npgsql.Internal.NpgsqlConnector._breakReason
member.summary: If this connector was broken, this contains the exception that caused the break.

summary.para: Used by the pool to indicate that I/O is currently in progress on this connector, so that another write isn't started concurrently. Note that since we have only one write loop, this is only ever usedto protect against an over-capacity writes into a connector that's currently *asynchronously* writing.
It is guaranteed that the currently-executing Specifically, reading may occur - and the connector may even be returned to the pool - before this is released.

member.name: P:Npgsql.Internal.NpgsqlConnector.UserTimeout
member.summary: The timeout for reading messages that are part of the user's command (i.e. which aren't internal prepended commands).

member.name: P:Npgsql.Internal.NpgsqlConnector.CancelLock
member.summary: A lock that's taken while a cancellation is being delivered; new queries are blocked until the cancellation is delivered. This reduces the chance that a cancellation meant for a previous command will accidentally cancel a later one, see #615.

member.name: P:Npgsql.Internal.NpgsqlConnector.SyncObj
member.summary: A lock that's taken to make sure no other concurrent operation is running. Break takes it to set the state of the connector. Anyone else should immediately check the state and exit if the connector is closed.

member.name: P:Npgsql.Internal.NpgsqlConnector.CleanupLock
member.summary: A lock that's used to wait for the Cleanup to complete while breaking the connection.

member.name: F:Npgsql.Internal.NpgsqlConnector._currentCommand
member.summary: The command currently being executed by the connector, null otherwise. Used only for concurrent use error reporting purposes.

member.summary: The connector source (e.g. pool) from where this connector came, and to which it will be returned. Note that in multi-host scenarios, this references the host-specific rather than the .

member.name: M:Npgsql.Internal.NpgsqlConnector.PerformPostgresCancellation
member.summary: Creates another connector and sends a cancel request through it for this connector. This method never throws, but returns whether the cancellation attempt failed.

returns.para: if the cancellation request was successfully delivered, or if it was skipped because a previous request was already sent. if the cancellation request could not be delivered because of an exception (the method logs internally).
This does not indicate whether the cancellation attempt was successful on the PostgreSQL side - only if the request was delivered.

member.name: M:Npgsql.Internal.NpgsqlConnector.StartNestedCancellableOperation(System.Threading.CancellationToken,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Starts a new cancellable operation within an ongoing user action. This should only be used if a single user action spans several different actions which each has its own cancellation tokens. For example, a command execution is a single user action, but spans ExecuteReaderQuery, NextResult, Read and so forth.
member.remarks: Only one level of nested operations is supported. It is an error to call this method if it has previously been called, and the returned was not disposed.
member.param: The cancellation token provided by the user. Callbacks will be registered on this token for executing the cancellation, and the token will be included in any thrown .

If , PostgreSQL cancellation will be attempted when the user requests cancellation or a timeout occurs, followed by a client-side socket cancellation once has elapsed. If , PostgreSQL cancellation will be skipped and client-socket cancellation will occur immediately.

member.name: M:Npgsql.Internal.NpgsqlConnector.CloseOngoingOperations(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Closes ongoing operations, i.e. an open reader exists or a COPY operation still in progress, as part of a connection close.

member.name: M:Npgsql.Internal.NpgsqlConnector.UnexpectedMessageReceived(Npgsql.BackendMessageCode)
member.summary: Called when an unexpected message has been received during an action. Breaks the connector and returns the appropriate message.

member.name: M:Npgsql.Internal.NpgsqlConnector.Break(System.Exception)
member.summary: Called when a connector becomes completely unusable, e.g. when an unexpected I/O exception is raised or when we lose protocol sync. Note that fatal errors during the Open phase do *not* pass through here.
member.param: The exception that caused the break.
member.returns: The exception given in for chaining calls.

member.name: M:Npgsql.Internal.NpgsqlConnector.Cleanup
member.summary: Closes the socket and cleans up client-side resources associated with this connector.
member.remarks: This method doesn't actually perform any meaningful I/O, and therefore is sync-only.

member.name: M:Npgsql.Internal.NpgsqlConnector.Reset(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Called when a pooled connection is closed, and its connector is returned to the pool. Resets the connector back to its initial state, releasing server-side sources (e.g. prepared statements), resetting parameters to their defaults, and resetting client-side state

member.name: M:Npgsql.Internal.NpgsqlConnector.ResetReadBuffer
member.summary: The connector may have allocated an oversize read buffer, to hold big rows in non-sequential reading. This switches us back to the original one and returns the buffer to .

member.name: M:Npgsql.Internal.NpgsqlConnector.StartUserAction(Npgsql.Internal.ConnectorState,Npgsql.NpgsqlCommand,System.Threading.CancellationToken,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Starts a user action. This makes sure that another action isn't already in progress, handles synchronization with keepalive, and sets up cancellation.
member.param: The new state to be set when entering this user action.
The that is starting execution - if an is thrown, it will reference this.
The cancellation token provided by the user. Callbacks will be registered on this token for executing the cancellation, and the token will be included in any thrown .

If , PostgreSQL cancellation will be attempted when the user requests cancellation or a timeout occurs, followed by a client-side socket cancellation once has elapsed. If , PostgreSQL cancellation will be skipped and client-socket cancellation will occur immediately.

member.summary: Non-generic base class for all type handlers which handle PostgreSQL arrays. Extend from instead.

https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/arrays.html.
The type handler API allows customizing Npgsql's behavior in powerful ways. However, although it is public, it should be considered somewhat unstable, and may change in breaking ways, including in non-major releases. Use it at your own risk.

member.name: T:Npgsql.Internal.TypeHandlers.BitStringHandler
member.summary: A type handler for the PostgreSQL bit string data type.
member.remarks:
See https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/datatype-bit.html.
Note that for BIT(1), this handler will return a bool by default, to align with SQLClient (see discussion https://github.com/npgsql/npgsql/pull/362#issuecomment-59622101).
The type handler API allows customizing Npgsql's behavior in powerful ways. However, although it is public, it should be considered somewhat unstable, and may change in breaking ways, including in non-major releases. Use it at your own risk.

member.name: T:Npgsql.Internal.TypeHandlers.BitStringArrayHandler
member.summary: A special handler for arrays of bit strings. Differs from the standard array handlers in that it returns arrays of bool for BIT(1) and arrays of BitArray otherwise (just like the scalar BitStringHandler does).
member.remarks: The type handler API allows customizing Npgsql's behavior in powerful ways. However, although it is public, it should be considered somewhat unstable, and may change in breaking ways, including in non-major releases. Use it at your own risk.

member.name: T:Npgsql.Internal.TypeHandlers.RecordHandler
member.summary: Type handler for PostgreSQL record types. Defaults to returning object[], but can also return or .
member.remarks:
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/datatype-pseudo.html
Encoding (identical to composite): A 32-bit integer with the number of columns, then for each column: * An OID indicating the type of the column * The length of the column(32-bit integer), or -1 if null * The column data encoded as binary

member.name: T:Npgsql.Internal.TypeHandlers.UnknownTypeHandler
member.summary: Handles "conversions" for columns sent by the database with unknown OIDs. This differs from TextHandler in that its a text-only handler (we don't want to receive binary representations of the types registered here). Note that this handler is also used in the very initial query that loads the OID mappings (chicken and egg problem). Also used for sending parameters with unknown types (OID=0)

member.name: M:Npgsql.Internal.TypeHandling.INpgsqlSimpleTypeHandler`1.Read(Npgsql.Internal.NpgsqlReadBuffer,System.Int32,Npgsql.BackendMessages.FieldDescription)
member.summary: Reads a value of type with the given length from the provided buffer, with the assumption that it is entirely present in the provided memory buffer and no I/O will be required.
member.param: The buffer from which to read.
The byte length of the value. The buffer might not contain the full length, requiring I/O to be performed.
Additional PostgreSQL information about the type, such as the length in varchar(30).
member.returns: The fully-read value.

member.name: M:Npgsql.Internal.TypeHandling.INpgsqlSimpleTypeHandler`1.ValidateAndGetLength(`0,Npgsql.NpgsqlParameter)
member.summary: Responsible for validating that a value represents a value of the correct and which can be written for PostgreSQL - if the value cannot be written for any reason, an exception should be thrown. Also returns the byte length needed to write the value.
member.param: The value to be written to PostgreSQL
The instance where this value resides. Can be used to access additional information relevant to the write process (e.g. ).
member.returns: The number of bytes required to write the value.

member.name: M:Npgsql.Internal.TypeHandling.INpgsqlSimpleTypeHandler`1.Write(`0,Npgsql.Internal.NpgsqlWriteBuffer,Npgsql.NpgsqlParameter)

member.param: The value to write.
The buffer to which to write.
The instance where this value resides. Can be used to access additional information relevant to the write process (e.g. ).

member.name: T:Npgsql.Internal.TypeHandling.INpgsqlTypeHandler`1
member.summary: Type handlers that wish to support reading other types in additional to the main one can implement this interface for all those types.

member.name: M:Npgsql.Internal.TypeHandling.INpgsqlTypeHandler`1.Read(Npgsql.Internal.NpgsqlReadBuffer,System.Int32,System.Boolean,Npgsql.BackendMessages.FieldDescription)
member.summary: Reads a value of type with the given length from the provided buffer, using either sync or async I/O.
member.param: The buffer from which to read.
The byte length of the value. The buffer might not contain the full length, requiring I/O to be performed.
If I/O is required to read the full length of the value, whether it should be performed synchronously or asynchronously.
Additional PostgreSQL information about the type, such as the length in varchar(30).
member.returns: The fully-read value.

A cache where the length calculated during the validation phase can be stored for use at the writing phase.
The instance where this value resides. Can be used to access additional information relevant to the write process (e.g. ).

member.name: M:Npgsql.Internal.TypeHandling.INpgsqlTypeHandler`1.Write(`0,Npgsql.Internal.NpgsqlWriteBuffer,Npgsql.Internal.TypeHandling.NpgsqlLengthCache,Npgsql.NpgsqlParameter,System.Boolean,System.Threading.CancellationToken)

member.name: T:Npgsql.Internal.TypeHandling.ITextReaderHandler
member.summary: Implemented by handlers which support , returns a standard TextReader given a binary Stream.

member.name: T:Npgsql.Internal.TypeHandling.NpgsqlLengthCache
member.summary:
An array of cached lengths for the parameters sending process.
When sending parameters, lengths need to be calculated more than once (once for Bind, once for an array, once for the string within that array). This cache optimizes that. Lengths are added to the cache, and then retrieved in the same order.

member.name: M:Npgsql.Internal.TypeHandling.NpgsqlLengthCache.Set(System.Int32)
member.summary: Stores a length value in the cache, to be fetched later via . Called at the phase.
member.returns: The length parameter.

member.name: M:Npgsql.Internal.TypeHandling.NpgsqlLengthCache.Get
member.summary: Retrieves a length value previously stored in the cache via . Called at the writing phase, after validation has already occurred and the length cache is populated.

member.name: T:Npgsql.Internal.TypeHandling.NpgsqlSimpleTypeHandler`1
member.summary: Base class for all simple type handlers, which read and write short, non-arbitrary lengthed values to PostgreSQL. Provides a simpler API to implement when compared to - Npgsql takes care of all I/O before calling into this type, so no I/O needs to be performed by it.
member.typeparam: The default CLR type that this handler will read and write. For example, calling on a column with this handler will return a value with type . Type handlers can support additional types by implementing .

member.name: T:Npgsql.NoSynchronizationContextScope
member.summary:
This mechanism is used to temporarily set the current synchronization context to null while executing Npgsql code, making all await continuations execute on the thread pool. This replaces the need to place ConfigureAwait(false) everywhere, and should be used in all surface async methods, without exception.
Warning: do not use this directly in async methods, use it in sync wrappers of async methods (see https://github.com/npgsql/npgsql/issues/1593)

member.name: P:Npgsql.NpgsqlBatch.EnableErrorBarriers
member.summary: Controls whether to place error barriers between all batch commands within this batch. Default to .

remarks.para: By default, any exception in a command causes later commands in the batch to be skipped, and earlier commands to be rolled back. Enabling error barriers ensures that errors do not affect other commands in the batch.

Note that if the batch is executed within an explicit transaction, the first error places the transaction in a failed state, causing all later commands to fail in any case. As a result, this option is useful mainly when there is no explicit transaction.
At the PostgreSQL wire protocol level, this corresponds to inserting a Sync message between each command, rather than grouping all the batch's commands behind a single terminating Sync.
To control error barriers on a command-by-command basis, see .

member.name: P:Npgsql.NpgsqlBatch.AllResultTypesAreUnknown
member.summary: Marks all of the batch's result columns as either known or unknown. Unknown results column are requested them from PostgreSQL in text format, and Npgsql makes no attempt to parse them. They will be accessible as strings only.

member.name: M:Npgsql.NpgsqlBatch.#ctor(Npgsql.NpgsqlConnection,Npgsql.NpgsqlTransaction)
member.summary: Initializes a new .
member.param: A that represents the connection to a PostgreSQL server.
The in which the executes.

member.name: P:Npgsql.NpgsqlBatchCommand.AppendErrorBarrier
member.summary: Appends an error barrier after this batch command. Defaults to the value of on the batch.

remarks.para: By default, any exception in a command causes later commands in the batch to be skipped, and earlier commands to be rolled back. Appending an error barrier ensures that errors from this command (or previous ones) won't cause later commands to be skipped, and that errors from later commands won't cause this command (or previous ones) to be rolled back).

Note that if the batch is executed within an explicit transaction, the first error places the transaction in a failed state, causing all later commands to fail in any case. As a result, this option is useful mainly when there is no explicit transaction.
At the PostgreSQL wire protocol level, this corresponds to inserting a Sync message after this command, rather than grouping all the batch's commands behind a single terminating Sync.
Controlling error barriers on a command-by-command basis is an advanced feature, consider enabling error barriers for the entire batch via .

summary.para: Terminates the ongoing binary import and puts the connection back into the idle state, where regular commands can be executed.
Note that if hasn't been invoked before calling this, the import will be cancelled and all changes will be reverted.

member.name: P:Npgsql.NpgsqlCommand.AllResultTypesAreUnknown
member.summary: Marks all of the query's result columns as either known or unknown. Unknown result columns are requested from PostgreSQL in text format, and Npgsql makes no attempt to parse them. They will be accessible as strings only.

member.name: P:Npgsql.NpgsqlCommand.UnknownResultTypeList
member.summary: Marks the query's result columns as known or unknown, on a column-by-column basis. Unknown result columns are requested from PostgreSQL in text format, and Npgsql makes no attempt to parse them. They will be accessible as strings only.
member.remarks:
If the query includes several queries (e.g. SELECT 1; SELECT 2), this will only apply to the first one. The rest of the queries will be fetched and parsed as usual.
The array size must correspond exactly to the number of result columns the query returns, or an error will be raised.

member.name: P:Npgsql.NpgsqlCommand.ObjectResultTypes
member.summary: Marks result types to be used when using GetValue on a data reader, on a column-by-column basis. Used for Entity Framework 5-6 compability. Only primitive numerical types and DateTimeOffset are supported. Set the whole array or just a value to null to use default type.

member.name: P:Npgsql.NpgsqlConnection.ProvidePasswordCallback
member.summary: Gets or sets the delegate used to generate a password for new database connections.

remarks.p: This delegate is executed when a new database connection is opened that requires a password.
The and connection string properties have precedence over this delegate: it will not be executed if a password is specified, or if the specified or default Passfile contains a valid entry.
Due to connection pooling this delegate is only executed when a new physical connection is opened, not when reusing a connection that was previously opened from the pool.

member.name: E:Npgsql.NpgsqlConnection.Notice
member.summary: Fires when PostgreSQL notices are received from PostgreSQL.
member.remarks:
PostgreSQL notices are non-critical messages generated by PostgreSQL, either as a result of a user query (e.g. as a warning or informational notice), or due to outside activity (e.g. if the database administrator initiates a "fast" database shutdown).
Note that notices are very different from notifications (see the event).

member.name: E:Npgsql.NpgsqlConnection.Notification
member.summary: Fires when PostgreSQL notifications are received from PostgreSQL.
member.remarks:
PostgreSQL notifications are sent when your connection has registered for notifications on a specific channel via the LISTEN command. NOTIFY can be used to generate such notifications, allowing for an inter-connection communication channel.
Note that notifications are very different from notices (see the event).

member.name: M:Npgsql.NpgsqlConnection.BeginRawBinaryCopy(System.String)
member.summary: Begins a raw binary COPY operation (TO STDOUT or FROM STDIN), a high-performance data export/import mechanism to a PostgreSQL table. Note that unlike the other COPY API methods, doesn't implement any encoding/decoding and is unsuitable for structured import/export operation. It is useful mainly for exporting a table as an opaque blob, for the purpose of importing it back later.
member.param: A COPY TO STDOUT or COPY FROM STDIN SQL command
member.returns: A that can be used to read or write raw binary data.

member.name: M:Npgsql.NpgsqlConnection.BeginRawBinaryCopyAsync(System.String,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Begins a raw binary COPY operation (TO STDOUT or FROM STDIN), a high-performance data export/import mechanism to a PostgreSQL table. Note that unlike the other COPY API methods, doesn't implement any encoding/decoding and is unsuitable for structured import/export operation. It is useful mainly for exporting a table as an opaque blob, for the purpose of importing it back later.
member.param: A COPY TO STDOUT or COPY FROM STDIN SQL command
An optional token to cancel the asynchronous operation. The default value is None.
member.returns: A that can be used to read or write raw binary data.

member.summary: The time to wait (in seconds) while trying to execute a command before terminating the attempt and generating an error. Defaults to 30 seconds.

member.name: P:Npgsql.NpgsqlConnectionStringBuilder.InternalCommandTimeout
member.summary: The time to wait (in seconds) while trying to execute a an internal command before terminating the attempt and generating an error.

member.name: P:Npgsql.NpgsqlConnectionStringBuilder.CancellationTimeout
member.summary: The time to wait (in milliseconds) while trying to read a response for a cancellation request for a timed out or cancelled query, before terminating the attempt and generating an error. Zero for infinity, -1 to skip the wait. Defaults to 2000 milliseconds.

member.name: P:Npgsql.NpgsqlConnectionStringBuilder.EntityTemplateDatabase
member.summary: The database template to specify when creating a database in Entity Framework. If not specified, PostgreSQL defaults to "template1".

member.name: P:Npgsql.NpgsqlConnectionStringBuilder.EntityAdminDatabase
member.summary: The database admin to specify when creating and dropping a database in Entity Framework. This is needed because Npgsql needs to connect to a database in order to send the create/drop database command. If not specified, defaults to "template1". Check NpgsqlServices.UsingPostgresDBConnection for more information.

member.name: P:Npgsql.NpgsqlConnectionStringBuilder.KeepAlive

member.name: P:Npgsql.NpgsqlConnectionStringBuilder.TcpKeepAlive

member.name: P:Npgsql.NpgsqlConnectionStringBuilder.TcpKeepAliveTime
member.summary: The number of seconds of connection inactivity before a TCP keepalive query is sent. Use of this option is discouraged, use instead if possible. Set to 0 (the default) to disable.

member.name: P:Npgsql.NpgsqlConnectionStringBuilder.TcpKeepAliveInterval

member.name: P:Npgsql.NpgsqlConnectionStringBuilder.ReadBufferSize

member.name: P:Npgsql.NpgsqlConnectionStringBuilder.WriteBufferSize

member.name: P:Npgsql.NpgsqlConnectionStringBuilder.MaxAutoPrepare
member.summary: The maximum number SQL statements that can be automatically prepared at any given point. Beyond this number the least-recently-used statement will be recycled. Zero (the default) disables automatic preparation.

member.name: P:Npgsql.NpgsqlConnectionStringBuilder.AutoPrepareMinUsages
member.summary: The minimum number of usages an SQL statement is used before it's automatically prepared. Defaults to 5.

member.name: P:Npgsql.NpgsqlConnectionStringBuilder.NoResetOnClose
member.summary: If set to true, a pool connection's state won't be reset when it is closed (improves performance). Do not specify this unless you know what you're doing.

member.summary: No special server compatibility mode is active

member.summary: The server is an Amazon Redshift instance.

member.summary: The server is doesn't support full type loading from the PostgreSQL catalogs, support the basic set of types via information hardcoded inside Npgsql.

member.name: T:Npgsql.SslMode
member.summary: Specifies how to manage SSL.

member.name: F:Npgsql.SslMode.Disable
member.summary: SSL is disabled. If the server requires SSL, the connection will fail.

member.name: F:Npgsql.SslMode.Allow
member.summary: Prefer non-SSL connections if the server allows them, but allow SSL connections.

member.name: F:Npgsql.SslMode.Prefer
member.summary: Prefer SSL connections if the server allows them, but allow connections without SSL.

member.name: F:Npgsql.SslMode.Require
member.summary: Fail the connection if the server doesn't support SSL.

member.name: F:Npgsql.SslMode.VerifyCA
member.summary: Fail the connection if the server doesn't support SSL. Also verifies server certificate.

member.name: F:Npgsql.SslMode.VerifyFull
member.summary: Fail the connection if the server doesn't support SSL. Also verifies server certificate with host's name.

member.name: T:Npgsql.ArrayNullabilityMode
member.summary: Specifies how the mapping of arrays of value types behaves with respect to nullability when they are requested via an API returning an .

member.name: F:Npgsql.ArrayNullabilityMode.Never
member.summary: Arrays of value types are always returned as non-nullable arrays (e.g. int[]). If the PostgreSQL array contains a NULL value, an exception is thrown. This is the default mode.

member.name: F:Npgsql.ArrayNullabilityMode.Always
member.summary: Arrays of value types are always returned as nullable arrays (e.g. int?[]).

member.name: F:Npgsql.ArrayNullabilityMode.PerInstance
member.summary: The type of array that gets returned is determined at runtime. Arrays of value types are returned as non-nullable arrays (e.g. int[]) if the actual instance that gets returned doesn't contain null values and as nullable arrays (e.g. int?[]) if it does.
member.remarks: When using this setting, make sure that your code is prepared to the fact that the actual type of array instances returned from APIs like may change on a row by row base.

member.name: T:Npgsql.ReplicationMode
member.summary: Specifies whether the connection shall be initialized as a physical or logical replication connection
member.remarks:
This enum and its corresponding property are intentionally kept internal as they should not be set by users or even be visible in their connection strings. Replication connections are a special kind of connection that is encapsulated in
and .

member.name: F:Npgsql.ReplicationMode.Off
member.summary: Replication disabled. This is the default

member.name: F:Npgsql.ReplicationMode.Physical
member.summary: Physical replication enabled

member.name: F:Npgsql.ReplicationMode.Logical
member.summary: Logical replication enabled

member.name: P:Npgsql.NpgsqlDataReader.Statements
member.summary: Returns details about each statement that this reader will or has executed.
member.remarks:
Note that some fields (i.e. rows and oid) are only populated as the reader traverses the result.
For commands with multiple queries, this exposes the number of rows affected on a statement-by-statement basis, unlike which exposes an aggregation across all statements.

member.summary: Enables parameters to be included in logging. This includes potentially sensitive information from data sent to PostgreSQL. You should only enable this flag in development, or if you have the appropriate security measures in place based on the sensitivity of this data.

member.name: M:Npgsql.NpgsqlDataSourceBuilder.UseUserCertificateValidationCallback(System.Net.Security.RemoteCertificateValidationCallback)
member.summary: When using SSL/TLS, this is a callback that allows customizing how the PostgreSQL-provided certificate is verified. This is an advanced API, consider using or instead.
member.param: The callback containing custom callback verification logic.

remarks.para: Cannot be used in conjunction with , or .

member.returns: The same builder instance so that multiple calls can be chained.

member.name: M:Npgsql.NpgsqlDataSourceBuilder.UseClientCertificate(System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Certificate)
member.summary: Specifies an SSL/TLS certificate which Npgsql will send to PostgreSQL for certificate-based authentication.
member.param: The client certificate to be sent to PostgreSQL when opening a connection.
member.returns: The same builder instance so that multiple calls can be chained.

member.name: M:Npgsql.NpgsqlDataSourceBuilder.UseClientCertificates(System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509CertificateCollection)
member.summary: Specifies a collection of SSL/TLS certificates which Npgsql will send to PostgreSQL for certificate-based authentication.
member.param: The client certificate collection to be sent to PostgreSQL when opening a connection.
member.returns: The same builder instance so that multiple calls can be chained.

member.name: M:Npgsql.NpgsqlDataSourceBuilder.UseClientCertificatesCallback(System.Action{System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509CertificateCollection})
member.summary: Specifies a callback to modify the collection of SSL/TLS client certificates which Npgsql will send to PostgreSQL for certificate-based authentication. This is an advanced API, consider using or instead.
member.param: The callback to modify the client certificate collection.

remarks.para: The callback is invoked every time a physical connection is opened, and is therefore suitable for rotating short-lived client certificates. Simply make sure the certificate collection argument has the up-to-date certificate(s).
The callback's collection argument already includes any client certificates specified via the connection string or environment variables.

member.returns: The same builder instance so that multiple calls can be chained.

member.name: M:Npgsql.NpgsqlDataSourceBuilder.UsePeriodicPasswordProvider(System.Func{Npgsql.NpgsqlConnectionStringBuilder,System.Threading.CancellationToken,System.Threading.Tasks.ValueTask{System.String}},System.TimeSpan,System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Configures a periodic password provider, which is automatically called by the data source at some regular interval. This is the recommended way to fetch a rotating access token.
member.param: A callback which returns the password to be sent to PostgreSQL.
How long to cache the password before re-invoking the callback.
If a password refresh attempt fails, it will be re-attempted with this interval. This should typically be much lower than .
member.returns: The same builder instance so that multiple calls can be chained.

remarks.para: The provided callback is invoked in a timer, and not when opening connections. It therefore doesn't affect opening time.
The provided cancellation token is only triggered when the entire data source is disposed. If you'd like to apply a timeout to the token fetching, do so within the provided callback.

member.name: M:Npgsql.NpgsqlDataSourceBuilder.UsePhysicalConnectionInitializer(System.Action{Npgsql.NpgsqlConnection},System.Func{Npgsql.NpgsqlConnection,System.Threading.Tasks.Task})
member.summary: Register a connection initializer, which allows executing arbitrary commands when a physical database connection is first opened.
member.param: A synchronous connection initialization lambda, which will be called from when a new physical connection is opened.
An asynchronous connection initialization lambda, which will be called from when a new physical connection is opened.
member.remarks: If an initializer is registered, both sync and async versions must be provided. If you do not use sync APIs in your code, simply throw , which would also catch accidental cases of sync opening.

Take care that the setting you apply in the initializer does not get reverted when the connection is returned to the pool, since Npgsql sends DISCARD ALL by default. The option can be used to turn this off.
member.returns: The same builder instance so that multiple calls can be chained.

member.name: M:Npgsql.NpgsqlLargeObjectManager.OpenRead(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Opens a large object on the backend, returning a stream controlling this remote object. A transaction snapshot is taken by the backend when the object is opened with only read permissions. When reading from this object, the contents reflects the time when the snapshot was taken. Note that this method, as well as operations on the stream must be wrapped inside a transaction.
member.param: Oid of the object
member.returns: An NpgsqlLargeObjectStream

member.name: T:Npgsql.PostgresException
member.summary: The exception that is thrown when the PostgreSQL backend reports errors (e.g. query SQL issues, constraint violations).
member.remarks:
This exception only corresponds to a PostgreSQL-delivered error. Other errors (e.g. network issues) will be raised via , and purely Npgsql-related issues which aren't related to the server will be raised via the standard CLR exceptions (e.g. ).
See https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/errcodes-appendix.html, https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/protocol-error-fields.html

member.name: P:Npgsql.PostgresException.IsTransient
member.summary: Specifies whether the exception is considered transient, that is, whether retrying the operation could succeed (e.g. a network error). Check .

member.name: P:Npgsql.PostgresException.Severity
member.summary: Severity of the error or notice. Always present.

member.name: P:Npgsql.PostgresException.InvariantSeverity
member.summary: Severity of the error or notice, not localized. Always present since PostgreSQL 9.6.

member.name: P:Npgsql.PostgresException.SqlState
member.summary: The SQLSTATE code for the error.
member.remarks: Always present. Constants are defined in . See https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/errcodes-appendix.html

member.name: P:Npgsql.PostgresException.Code
member.summary: The SQLSTATE code for the error.
member.remarks: Always present. Constants are defined in . See https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/errcodes-appendix.html

member.name: P:Npgsql.PostgresException.MessageText
member.summary: The primary human-readable error message. This should be accurate but terse.

member.name: P:Npgsql.PostgresException.Detail
member.summary: An optional secondary error message carrying more detail about the problem. May run to multiple lines.

member.name: P:Npgsql.PostgresException.Hint
member.summary: An optional suggestion what to do about the problem. This is intended to differ from Detail in that it offers advice (potentially inappropriate) rather than hard facts. May run to multiple lines.

member.name: P:Npgsql.PostgresException.Position
member.summary: The field value is a decimal ASCII integer, indicating an error cursor position as an index into the original query string. The first character has index 1, and positions are measured in characters not bytes. 0 means not provided.

member.name: P:Npgsql.PostgresException.InternalPosition
member.summary: This is defined the same as the field, but it is used when the cursor position refers to an internally generated command rather than the one submitted by the client. The field will always appear when this field appears. 0 means not provided.

member.name: P:Npgsql.PostgresException.InternalQuery
member.summary: The text of a failed internally-generated command. This could be, for example, a SQL query issued by a PL/pgSQL function.

member.name: P:Npgsql.PostgresException.Where
member.summary: An indication of the context in which the error occurred. Presently this includes a call stack traceback of active PL functions. The trace is one entry per line, most recent first.

member.name: P:Npgsql.PostgresException.SchemaName
member.summary: If the error was associated with a specific database object, the name of the schema containing that object, if any.

member.name: P:Npgsql.PostgresException.TableName
member.summary: Table name: if the error was associated with a specific table, the name of the table. (Refer to the schema name field for the name of the table's schema.)

member.name: P:Npgsql.PostgresException.ColumnName
member.summary: If the error was associated with a specific table column, the name of the column. (Refer to the schema and table name fields to identify the table.)

member.name: P:Npgsql.PostgresException.DataTypeName
member.summary: If the error was associated with a specific data type, the name of the data type. (Refer to the schema name field for the name of the data type's schema.)

member.name: P:Npgsql.PostgresException.ConstraintName
member.summary: If the error was associated with a specific constraint, the name of the constraint. Refer to fields listed above for the associated table or domain. (For this purpose, indexes are treated as constraints, even if they weren't created with constraint syntax.)

member.name: P:Npgsql.PostgresException.File
member.summary: The file name of the source-code location where the error was reported.

member.name: P:Npgsql.PostgresException.Line
member.summary: The line number of the source-code location where the error was reported.

member.name: P:Npgsql.PostgresException.Routine
member.summary: The name of the source-code routine reporting the error.

member.name: T:Npgsql.PostgresTypes.PostgresDomainType
member.summary: Represents a PostgreSQL domain type.
member.remarks:
See https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/sql-createdomain.html.
When PostgreSQL returns a RowDescription for a domain type, the type OID is the base type's (so fetching a domain type over text returns a RowDescription for text). However, when a composite type is returned, the type OID there is that of the domain, so we provide "clean" support for domain types.

member.summary: If true, the user explicitly requested this statement be prepared. It does not get closed as part of the automatic preparation LRU mechanism.

member.name: F:Npgsql.PreparedStatement.StatementBeingReplaced
member.summary: If this statement is about to be prepared, but replaces a previous statement which needs to be closed, this holds the name of the previous statement. Otherwise null.

member.name: P:Npgsql.PreparedStatement.HandlerParamTypes
member.summary: Contains the handler types for a prepared statement's parameters, for overloaded cases (same SQL, different param types) Only populated after the statement has been prepared (i.e. null for candidates).

member.name: T:Npgsql.PreparedState
member.summary: The state of a .

member.name: F:Npgsql.PreparedState.NotPrepared
member.summary: The statement hasn't been prepared yet, nor is it in the process of being prepared. This is the value for autoprepare candidates which haven't been prepared yet, and is also a temporary state during preparation.

member.name: F:Npgsql.PreparedState.BeingPrepared
member.summary: The statement is in the process of being prepared.

member.name: F:Npgsql.PreparedState.Prepared
member.summary: The statement has been fully prepared and can be executed.

member.name: F:Npgsql.PreparedState.BeingUnprepared
member.summary: The statement is in the process of being unprepared. This is a temporary state that only occurs during unprepare. Specifically, it means that a Close message for the statement has already been written to the write buffer.

member.name: F:Npgsql.PreparedState.Unprepared
member.summary: The statement has been unprepared and is no longer usable.

member.name: F:Npgsql.PreparedState.Invalidated
member.summary: The statement was invalidated because e.g. table schema has changed since preparation.

member.name: F:Npgsql.PreparedStatementManager.NumPrepared

member.name: T:Npgsql.Replication.Internal.LogicalReplicationConnectionExtensions
member.summary: This API is for internal use and for implementing logical replication plugins. It is not meant to be consumed in common Npgsql usage scenarios.
This API is for internal use and for implementing logical replication plugins. It is not meant to be consumed in common Npgsql usage scenarios.
member.remarks: Creates a new replication slot and returns information about the newly-created slot.
member.param: The to use for creating the replication slot

The name of the slot to create. Must be a valid replication slot name (see
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/warm-standby.html#STREAMING-REPLICATION-SLOTS-MANIPULATION).

The name of the output plugin used for logical decoding (see
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/logicaldecoding-output-plugin.html).
if this replication slot shall be temporary one; otherwise . Temporary slots are not saved to disk and are automatically dropped on error or when the session has finished.

A to specify what to do with the snapshot created during logical slot initialization. , which is also the default, will export the snapshot for use in other sessions. This option can't be used inside a transaction. will use the snapshot for the current transaction executing the command. This option must be used in a transaction, and must be the first command run in that transaction. Finally, will just use the snapshot for logical decoding as normal but won't do anything else with it.

If , this logical replication slot supports decoding of two-phase transactions. With this option, two-phase commands like PREPARE TRANSACTION, COMMIT PREPARED and ROLLBACK PREPARED are decoded and transmitted. The transaction will be decoded and transmitted at PREPARE TRANSACTION time. The default is .
An optional token to cancel the asynchronous operation. The default value is .
member.returns: A representing a class that can be used to initialize instances of subclasses.

member.summary: Instructs the server to start streaming the WAL for logical replication, starting at WAL location or at the slot's consistent point if isn't specified. The server can reply with an error, for example if the requested section of the WAL has already been recycled.
member.param: The to use for starting replication
The replication slot that will be updated as replication progresses so that the server knows which WAL segments are still needed by the standby.
The token to monitor for stopping the replication.
The WAL location to begin streaming at.
The collection of options passed to the slot's logical decoding plugin.
Whether the plugin will be bypassing and reading directly from the buffer.
member.returns: A representing an that can be used to stream WAL entries in form of instances.

member.name: T:Npgsql.Replication.PgOutputConnectionExtensions
member.summary: Extension methods to use with the pg_output logical decoding plugin.

member.name: M:Npgsql.Replication.PgOutputConnectionExtensions.CreatePgOutputReplicationSlot(Npgsql.Replication.LogicalReplicationConnection,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Nullable{Npgsql.Replication.LogicalSlotSnapshotInitMode},System.Boolean,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Creates a class that wraps a replication slot using the "pgoutput" logical decoding plugin and can be used to start streaming replication via the logical streaming replication protocol.
member.param: The to use for creating the replication slot
The name of the slot to create. Must be a valid replication slot name (see https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/warm-standby.html#STREAMING-REPLICATION-SLOTS-MANIPULATION).
if this replication slot shall be temporary one; otherwise . Temporary slots are not saved to disk and are automatically dropped on error or when the session has finished.

A to specify what to do with the snapshot created during logical slot initialization. , which is also the default, will export the snapshot for use in other sessions. This option can't be used inside a transaction. will use the snapshot for the current transaction executing the command. This option must be used in a transaction, and must be the first command run in that transaction. Finally, will just use the snapshot for logical decoding as normal but won't do anything else with it.

If , this logical replication slot supports decoding of two-phase transactions. With this option, two-phase commands like PREPARE TRANSACTION, COMMIT PREPARED and ROLLBACK PREPARED are decoded and transmitted. The transaction will be decoded and transmitted at PREPARE TRANSACTION time. The default is .
An optional token to cancel the asynchronous operation. The default value is .
member.returns: A that wraps the newly-created replication slot.

member.summary: Instructs the server to start the Logical Streaming Replication Protocol (pgoutput logical decoding plugin), starting at WAL location or at the slot's consistent point if isn't specified. The server can reply with an error, for example if the requested section of the WAL has already been recycled.
member.param: The to use for starting replication
The replication slot that will be updated as replication progresses so that the server knows which WAL segments are still needed by the standby.
The collection of options passed to the slot's logical decoding plugin.
The token to monitor for stopping the replication.
The WAL location to begin streaming at.
member.returns: A representing an that can be used to stream WAL entries in form of instances.

member.summary: Creates a that wraps a PostgreSQL physical replication slot and can be used to start physical streaming replication
member.param: The name of the slot to create. Must be a valid replication slot name (see Section 26.2.6.1).
if this replication slot shall be a temporary one; otherwise . Temporary slots are not saved to disk and are automatically dropped on error or when the session has finished.
If this is set to this physical replication slot reserves WAL immediately. Otherwise, WAL is only reserved upon connection from a streaming replication client.
An optional token to cancel the asynchronous operation. The default value is .
member.returns: A representing a that represents the newly-created replication slot.

member.returns: A representing a or if the replication slot does not exist.

member.name: M:Npgsql.Replication.PhysicalReplicationConnection.StartReplication(Npgsql.Replication.PhysicalReplicationSlot,NpgsqlTypes.NpgsqlLogSequenceNumber,System.Threading.CancellationToken,System.UInt64)
member.summary: Instructs the server to start streaming the WAL for physical replication, starting at WAL location . The server can reply with an error, for example if the requested section of the WAL has already been recycled.
member.remarks: If the client requests a timeline that's not the latest but is part of the history of the server, the server will stream all the WAL on that timeline starting from the requested start point up to the point where the server switched to another timeline.
member.param: The replication slot that will be updated as replication progresses so that the server knows which WAL segments are still needed by the standby.
The WAL location to begin streaming at.
The token to be used for stopping the replication.
Streaming starts on timeline tli.
member.returns: A representing an that can be used to stream WAL entries in form of instances.

member.name: M:Npgsql.Replication.PhysicalReplicationConnection.StartReplication(NpgsqlTypes.NpgsqlLogSequenceNumber,System.Threading.CancellationToken,System.UInt64)
member.summary: Instructs the server to start streaming the WAL for logical replication, starting at WAL location . The server can reply with an error, for example if the requested section of WAL has already been recycled.
member.remarks: If the client requests a timeline that's not the latest but is part of the history of the server, the server will stream all the WAL on that timeline starting from the requested start point up to the point where the server switched to another timeline.
member.param: The WAL location to begin streaming at.
The token to be used for stopping the replication.
Streaming starts on timeline tli.
member.returns: A representing an that can be used to stream WAL entries in form of instances.

member.name: M:Npgsql.Replication.PhysicalReplicationConnection.StartReplication(Npgsql.Replication.PhysicalReplicationSlot,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Instructs the server to start streaming the WAL for physical replication, starting at the WAL location and timeline id specified in . The server can reply with an error, for example if the requested section of the WAL has already been recycled.
member.remarks: If the client requests a timeline that's not the latest but is part of the history of the server, the server will stream all the WAL on that timeline starting from the requested start point up to the point where the server switched to another timeline.
member.param:

member.name: M:Npgsql.Replication.ReplicationConnection.SetReplicationStatus(NpgsqlTypes.NpgsqlLogSequenceNumber)
member.summary:
Sets the current status of the replication as it is interpreted by the consuming client. The value supplied in will be sent to the server via and with the next status update.
A status update which will happen upon server request, upon expiration of our upon an enforced status update via , whichever happens first. If you want the value you set here to be pushed to the server immediately (e. g. in synchronous replication scenarios), call after calling this method.
member.remarks: This is a convenience method setting both and in one operation. You can use it if your application processes replication messages in a way that doesn't care about the difference between writing a message and flushing it to a permanent storage medium.
member.param: The location of the last WAL byte + 1 applied (e. g. processed or written to disk) and flushed to disk in the standby.

member.name: M:Npgsql.Replication.TestDecodingConnectionExtensions.CreateTestDecodingReplicationSlot(Npgsql.Replication.LogicalReplicationConnection,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Nullable{Npgsql.Replication.LogicalSlotSnapshotInitMode},System.Boolean,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Creates a class that wraps a replication slot using the test_decoding logical decoding plugin.
member.param: The to use for creating the replication slot
The name of the slot to create. Must be a valid replication slot name (see https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/warm-standby.html#STREAMING-REPLICATION-SLOTS-MANIPULATION).
if this replication slot shall be temporary one; otherwise . Temporary slots are not saved to disk and are automatically dropped on error or when the session has finished.

A to specify what to do with the snapshot created during logical slot initialization. , which is also the default, will export the snapshot for use in other sessions. This option can't be used inside a transaction. will use the snapshot for the current transaction executing the command. This option must be used in a transaction, and must be the first command run in that transaction. Finally, will just use the snapshot for logical decoding as normal but won't do anything else with it.

If , this logical replication slot supports decoding of two-phase transactions. With this option, two-phase commands like PREPARE TRANSACTION, COMMIT PREPARED and ROLLBACK PREPARED are decoded and transmitted. The transaction will be decoded and transmitted at PREPARE TRANSACTION time. The default is .
An optional token to cancel the asynchronous operation. The default value is .
member.returns: A that wraps the newly-created replication slot.

member.summary: Instructs the server to start streaming the WAL for logical replication using the test_decoding logical decoding plugin, starting at WAL location or at the slot's consistent point if isn't specified. The server can reply with an error, for example if the requested section of the WAL has already been recycled.
member.param: The to use for starting replication
The replication slot that will be updated as replication progresses so that the server knows which WAL segments are still needed by the standby.
The token to monitor for stopping the replication.
The collection of options passed to the slot's logical decoding plugin.
The WAL location to begin streaming at.
member.returns: A representing an that can be used to stream WAL entries in form of instances.

member.name: T:Npgsql.Replication.XLogDataMessage
member.summary: A message representing a section of the WAL data stream.

member.name: P:Npgsql.Replication.XLogDataMessage.Data
member.summary: A section of the WAL data stream that is raw WAL data in physical replication or decoded with the selected logical decoding plugin in logical replication. It is only valid until the next is requested from the stream.
member.remarks: A single WAL record is never split across two XLogData messages. When a WAL record crosses a WAL page boundary, and is therefore already split using continuation records, it can be split at the page boundary. In other words, the first main WAL record and its continuation records can be sent in different XLogData messages.

member.summary: A wrapper around to simplify reset management.
member.remarks: Since there's no way to reset a once it was cancelled, we need to make sure that an existing cancellation token source hasn't been cancelled, every time we start it (see https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/4694).

member.name: F:Npgsql.Util.ResettableCancellationTokenSource.lockObject
member.summary: Used, so we wouldn't concurently use the cts for the cancellation, while it's being disposed

member.param: An optional token to cancel the asynchronous operation. The default value is .
member.returns: The from the wrapped

member.summary: Reset the wrapper to contain a unstarted and uncancelled in order make sure the next call to will not invalidate the cancellation token.

member.name: M:Npgsql.Util.ResettableCancellationTokenSource.Stop
member.summary: Set the timeout on the wrapped to
member.remarks: can still arrive at a state where it's value is if the passed to gets a cancellation request. If this is the case it will be resolved upon the next call to or . Calling multiple times or without calling first will do no any harm (besides eating a tiny amount of CPU cycles).

member.summary: Cancel the wrapped

member.name: P:Npgsql.Util.ResettableCancellationTokenSource.Token
member.summary: The from the wrapped .
member.remarks: The token is only valid after calling and before calling the next time. Otherwise you may end up with a token that has already been cancelled or belongs to a cancellation token source that has been disposed.

member.name: T:Npgsql.VolatileResourceManager
member.remarks: Note that a connection may be closed before its TransactionScope completes. In this case we close the NpgsqlConnection as usual but the connector in a special list in the pool; it will be closed only when the scope completes.

member.name: T:NpgsqlTypes.NpgsqlLogSequenceNumber
member.summary: Wraps a PostgreSQL Write-Ahead Log Sequence Number (see: https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/datatype-pg-lsn.html)
member.remarks:
Log Sequence Numbers are a fundamental concept of the PostgreSQL Write-Ahead Log and by that of PostgreSQL replication. See https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/wal-internals.html for what they represent.
This struct provides conversions from/to and and beyond that tries to port the methods and operators in https://git.postgresql.org/gitweb/?p=postgresql.git;a=blob;f=src/backend/utils/adt/pg_lsn.c but nothing more.

member.name: M:NpgsqlTypes.NpgsqlLogSequenceNumber.TryParse(System.String,NpgsqlTypes.NpgsqlLogSequenceNumber@)
member.summary: Tries to convert the string representation of a Log Sequence Number to an instance. A return value indicates whether the conversion succeeded or failed.
member.param: A string that represents the Log Sequence Number to convert.

When this method returns, contains a instance equivalent to the Log Sequence Number contained in , if the conversion succeeded, or the default value for (0) if the conversion failed. The conversion fails if the parameter is or , is not in the right format, or represents a number less than or greater than . This parameter is passed uninitialized; any value originally supplied in result will be overwritten.
member.returns: if c> was converted successfully; otherwise, .

member.summary: Tries to convert the span representation of a Log Sequence Number to an instance. A return value indicates whether the conversion succeeded or failed.
member.param: A span containing the characters that represent the Log Sequence Number to convert.

When this method returns, contains a instance equivalent to the Log Sequence Number contained in , if the conversion succeeded, or the default value for (0) if the conversion failed. The conversion fails if the parameter is empty, is not in the right format, or represents a number less than or greater than . This parameter is passed uninitialized; any value originally supplied in result will be overwritten.
member.returns: if was converted successfully; otherwise, .

member.name: T:NpgsqlTypes.RangeFlags
member.summary: Represents characteristics of range type boundaries.

member.name: F:NpgsqlTypes.RangeFlags.None
member.summary: The default flag. The range is not empty and has boundaries that are definite and exclusive.

member.name: F:NpgsqlTypes.RangeFlags.Empty
member.summary: The range is empty. E.g. '(0,0)', 'empty'.

member.name: F:NpgsqlTypes.RangeFlags.LowerBoundInclusive
member.summary: The lower bound is inclusive. E.g. '[0,5]', '[0,5)', '[0,)'.

member.name: F:NpgsqlTypes.RangeFlags.UpperBoundInclusive
member.summary: The upper bound is inclusive. E.g. '[0,5]', '(0,5]', '(,5]'.

member.name: F:NpgsqlTypes.RangeFlags.LowerBoundInfinite
member.summary: The lower bound is infinite or indefinite. E.g. '(null,5]', '(-infinity,5]', '(,5]'.

member.name: F:NpgsqlTypes.RangeFlags.UpperBoundInfinite
member.summary: The upper bound is infinite or indefinite. E.g. '[0,null)', '[0,infinity)', '[0,)'.

member.name: F:NpgsqlTypes.RangeFlags.Inclusive
member.summary: Both the lower and upper bounds are inclusive.

member.name: F:NpgsqlTypes.RangeFlags.Infinite
member.summary: Both the lower and upper bounds are indefinite.

member.name: F:NpgsqlTypes.RangeFlags.LowerInclusiveInfinite
member.summary: The lower bound is both inclusive and indefinite. This represents an error condition.

member.name: F:NpgsqlTypes.RangeFlags.UpperInclusiveInfinite
member.summary: The upper bound is both inclusive and indefinite. This represents an error condition.
